articles.headline: Warm Winters Upset Rhythms of Maple Sugar
articles.snippet: Warmer-than-usual winters are stoking fears for the survival of New England’s maple forests.
articles.abstract: Warmer-than-usual winters are stoking fears for the survival of New England’s maple forests.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTPELIER, Vt. — One might expect Burr Morse to have maple sugaring down to a science.

articles.headline: Social Networking’s Next Phase
articles.snippet: More companies are helping large corporate clients create services resembling MySpace or YouTube to bring their customers together online.
articles.abstract: More companies are helping large corporate clients create services resembling MySpace or YouTube to bring their customers together online.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, March 2 — Next week Cisco Systems, a Silicon Valley heavyweight, plans to announce one of its most unusual deals: it is buying the technology assets of Tribe.net, a mostly forgotten social networking site, according to people close to the companies’ discussions.

articles.headline: Using the Web to Get the Boss to Pay More
articles.snippet: Most employees have little ammunition going into a meeting to talk about their pay, but a few Web sites are trying to level the playing field.
articles.abstract: Most employees have little ammunition going into a meeting to talk about their pay, but a few Web sites are trying to level the playing field.
articles.lead_paragraph: If information is power, then most employees who enter salary negotiations are holding pea shooters while the boss is encased in a Kevlar vest.

articles.headline: U.S. and Brazil Seek to Promote Ethanol in West
articles.snippet: President Bush is working with Brazil on an agreement to promote ethanol in Latin America and the Caribbean.
articles.abstract: President Bush is working with Brazil on an agreement to promote ethanol in Latin America and the Caribbean.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 2 — President Bush, hoping to reduce demand for oil in the Western Hemisphere, is preparing to finish an agreement with Brazil next week to promote the production and use of ethanol throughout Latin America and the Caribbean, according to administration officials.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Larry Rohter

articles.headline: After Tornado, an Alabama School Tallies the Grief
articles.snippet: Dazed survivors recounted their luck as they toured the perimeter of the painful ruins where eight students died.
articles.abstract: Dazed survivors recounted their luck as they toured the perimeter of the painful ruins where eight students died.
articles.lead_paragraph: ENTERPRISE, Ala., March 2 — After the sudden pitch-black darkness, there was chaos, then screaming. And when that subsided, the students of Enterprise High School recalled on Friday, some young men and women they had grown up with were nowhere to be found, while others climbed shakily to their feet.

articles.headline: Give Me a Double Shot of Starbucks Nostalgia
articles.snippet: There are two Howard Schultzes. One loves the smaller, more personal chain that Starbucks once was. The other understands Wall Street’s needs.
articles.abstract: There are two Howard Schultzes. One loves the smaller, more personal chain that Starbucks once was. The other understands Wall Street’s needs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is it possible that there are actually two Howard Schultzes lurking around Starbucks headquarters in Seattle? I think it is.

articles.headline: Authorities Investigate Big Lender
articles.snippet: Authorities are investigating stock sales and accounting errors at the New Century Financial Corporation, which specializes in subprime lending.
articles.abstract: Authorities are investigating stock sales and accounting errors at the New Century Financial Corporation, which specializes in subprime lending.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors and securities regulators are investigating stock sales and accounting errors at the New Century Financial Corporation, the biggest mortgage company that specializes in lending to people with weak, or subprime, credit, the company disclosed in a corporate filing yesterday.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: The Lot of the Consultant: Explaining What You Do
articles.snippet: For the growing number of independent consultants, going solo can offer greater flexibility, better compensation and more family time.
articles.abstract: For the growing number of independent consultants, going solo can offer greater flexibility, better compensation and more family time.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR the growing number of independent consultants, going solo can offer greater flexibility, better compensation and more family time than would generally be possible in corporate America.

articles.headline: That Ship Will Come in, Right?
articles.snippet: There is an argument to be made that if Wave Systems is ever going to succeed, the moment of truth has arrived.
articles.abstract: There is an argument to be made that if Wave Systems is ever going to succeed, the moment of truth has arrived.
articles.lead_paragraph: WAVE SYSTEMS has never had a profitable quarter. Ever. In nearly 20 years.

articles.headline: Doubts Rise as States Hold Sex Offenders After Prison
articles.snippet: Confining sex offenders past their terms has almost never met a stated purpose of treating the worst criminals until they no longer pose a threat.
articles.abstract: Confining sex offenders past their terms has almost never met a stated purpose of treating the worst criminals until they no longer pose a threat.
articles.lead_paragraph: The decision by New York to confine sex offenders beyond their prison terms places the state at the forefront of a growing national movement that is popular with politicians and voters. But such programs have almost never met a stated purpose of treating the worst criminals until they no longer pose a threat.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Abby Goodnough

articles.headline: Recalling Struggle for Civil Rights, Democrats Battle for Black Votes
articles.snippet: The Democratic candidates for president are embroiled in one of the most competitive scrambles for black supporters in decades.
articles.abstract: The Democratic candidates for president are embroiled in one of the most competitive scrambles for black supporters in decades.

articles.headline: A Teenage Soldier’s Goodbyes on the Road to Over There
articles.snippet: Pvt. Resha Kane, just 10 months removed from her senior prom, is bound for Fort Hood, and then probably Iraq.
articles.abstract: Pvt. Resha Kane, just 10 months removed from her senior prom, is bound for Fort Hood, and then probably Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOHAVE VALLEY, Ariz.

articles.headline: Mission Improbable: Tom Cruise as Mogul
articles.snippet: Hollywood is trying to make sense of the deal that put Tom Cruise and his business partner, Paula Wagner, in charge of the dormant United Artists studio.
articles.abstract: Hollywood is trying to make sense of the deal that put Tom Cruise and his business partner, Paula Wagner, in charge of the dormant United Artists studio.
articles.lead_paragraph: Los Angeles

articles.headline: In Baghdad, Sectarian Lines Too Deadly to Cross
articles.snippet: Some streets are bullet-riddled and abandoned danger zones — the boundaries between Sunni and Shiite areas.
articles.abstract: Some streets are bullet-riddled and abandoned danger zones — the boundaries between Sunni and Shiite areas.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, March 3 — After centuries full of vibrant interaction, of marrying, sharing and selling across sects and classes, Baghdad has become a capital of corrosive and violent borderlines. Streets never crossed. Conversations never started. Doors never entered.

articles.headline: Mortgages May Be Messier Than You Think
articles.snippet: Because so many players have an interest in keeping risks under wraps, a complete understanding of the home mortgage securities market’s ills may take time.
articles.abstract: Because so many players have an interest in keeping risks under wraps, a complete understanding of the home mortgage securities market’s ills may take time.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHAT investors don’t know about why the home mortgage securities market is in distress could fill volumes. As is often the case, only after fiery markets burn out do we see the risks that buyers ignore and sellers play down.

articles.headline: A Record of Failure at Center for Sex Offenders
articles.snippet: A treatment center for sex offenders is failing to meet its central purpose: preparing them to return to society.
articles.abstract: A treatment center for sex offenders is failing to meet its central purpose: preparing them to return to society.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARCADIA, Fla. — Inside a privately run treatment center here for pedophiles and rapists who have completed their prison sentences, where they are supposed to reflect on their crimes and learn to control their sexual urges, bikini posters were pinned to walls.
articles.byline: By Abby Goodnough and Monica Davey

articles.headline: Where Artists and Inventors Plot to Save the World
articles.snippet: More than 1,000 people will gather in Monterey, Calif., for the annual TED conference, named for the convergence of technology, entertainment and design.
articles.abstract: More than 1,000 people will gather in Monterey, Calif., for the annual TED conference, named for the convergence of technology, entertainment and design.
articles.lead_paragraph: “It’s starting to feel like Christmas and the family is coming in,” Chris Anderson said, in his almost whispering voice.

articles.headline: Mortgage Crisis Spirals, and Casualties Mount
articles.snippet: Large companies that bought subprime lenders during a boom in the market are now scrambling to sell them or scale back their exposure.
articles.abstract: Large companies that bought subprime lenders during a boom in the market are now scrambling to sell them or scale back their exposure.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even in affluent Orange County, Calif., the growing wealth of executives and brokers in the booming mortgage industry was hard to miss.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: D’Amato Never Folds
articles.snippet: Alfonse M. D’Amato, the former senator and a poker aficionado, is lobbying to overturn a new federal ban on Internet gambling.
articles.abstract: Alfonse M. D’Amato, the former senator and a poker aficionado, is lobbying to overturn a new federal ban on Internet gambling.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Alfonse M. D’Amato, the former Republican senator from New York, was the host at a Thursday evening poker game at his Capitol Hill office, playing with other lawmakers, staff members and lobbyists late into the night over pots that ranged from a few dollars to a few hundred.
articles.byline: By Gary Rivlin and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: Citizen Bono Brings Africa to Idle Rich
articles.snippet: As the guest editor of the July issue of Vanity Fair, Bono will try to rebrand Africa.
articles.abstract: As the guest editor of the July issue of Vanity Fair, Bono will try to rebrand Africa.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you are a rock star with a touch of the messiah complex, saving the world one song at a time has its limits. Even John Lennon didn’t make much progress on world peace before he died.

articles.headline: In Guatemala, Officers’ Killings Echo Dirty War
articles.snippet: Police corruption, lawlessness and drug traffic plague much of Central America, particularly Guatemala.
articles.abstract: Police corruption, lawlessness and drug traffic plague much of Central America, particularly Guatemala.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUATEMALA CITY, March 3  After three Salvadoran congressmen were waylaid and killed on a road in Guatemala last month, it did not take the authorities long to find the culprits: they were Guatemalan police officers, and their unmarked police car had a tracking device that proved they were at the scene.

articles.headline: Basra Raid Finds Dozens Detained by Iraq Spy Unit
articles.snippet: Iraqi and British forces found prisoners showing signs of torture inside the offices of an Iraqi intelligence agency.
articles.abstract: Iraqi and British forces found prisoners showing signs of torture inside the offices of an Iraqi intelligence agency.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Monday, March 5 — Iraqi special forces and British troops stormed the offices of an Iraqi government intelligence agency in the southern city of Basra on Sunday, and British officials said they discovered about 30 prisoners, some showing signs of torture.

articles.headline: Time Change a ‘Mini-Y2K’ in Tech Terms
articles.snippet: Companies are scrambling to reset computing devices as daylight saving time begins three weeks earlier.
articles.abstract: Companies are scrambling to reset computing devices as daylight saving time begins three weeks earlier.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, when Congress passed a law to extend daylight saving time by a month, the move seemed a harmless step that would let the nation burn a little less fossil fuel and enjoy a bit more sunshine.

articles.headline: Oil Innovations Pump New Life Into Old Wells
articles.snippet: Technology has unlocked more oil from old fields, challenging forecasts that  reserves are drying out.
articles.abstract: Technology has unlocked more oil from old fields, challenging forecasts that  reserves are drying out.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — The Kern River oil field, discovered in 1899, was revived when Chevron engineers here started injecting high-pressured steam to pump out more oil. The field, whose production had slumped to 10,000 barrels a day in the 1960s, now has a daily output of 85,000 barrels.

articles.headline: President Is Leaving N.A.A.C.P.
articles.snippet: Bruce S. Gordon’s resignation after 19 months on the job shocked the civil rights community.
articles.abstract: Bruce S. Gordon’s resignation after 19 months on the job shocked the civil rights community.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 4 — The president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said on Sunday that he was stepping down after only 19 months on the job, signaling divisions within the organization, the nation’s oldest and largest civil rights group.

articles.headline: Without Health Benefits, a Good Life Turns Fragile
articles.snippet: Solidly middle-class people are one of the fastest growing subgroups of uninsured Americans.
articles.abstract: Solidly middle-class people are one of the fastest growing subgroups of uninsured Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALISBURY, N.C. — Vicki H. Readling vividly remembers the start of 2006.
